Award.AwardTitle: Accounting for Baryons in Dark Energy Constraints: From DES to LSST
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to use simulations to understand corrections to the distribution of weak gravitational lensing effects caused by the particles that make up normal matter (known as "baryons"); gravitational lensing is the process in which large amounts of matter bend the light coming from more distant objects, located beyond the matter distributions. These simulations would reduce systematic errors for next-generation studies of the "dark energy" phenomenon that causes the accelerating expansion of the universe that use weak lensing. Broader impacts are substantial and include training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as public outreach. Dr. Zentner will give public lectures at the Allegheny Observatory, conduct educational events at the Carnegie Science Center Buhl Academy, organize the University of Pittsburgh's Astronomy Outreach Program, and lecture at continuing education events for public school teachers.

The program addresses the issue that all weak lensing surveys probe small scales where baryonic effects become important in the interpretation of dark energy studies, and includes carefully planned steps to deal with these effects. A key strength is the use of multiple approaches to model the effects of baryons: parameterizing baryonic effects by modifying density profiles; using blind analyses of simulations with different baryonic effects; cluster expansion methods; and Lagrangian methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Universe is expanding. As a matter of fact, the Universal expansion is accelerating for a reason that has yet to be understood. The quest for the cause of the accelerated expansion of the Universe is among the highest priorities in physics and astronomy. Developing an understanding of the causes of the acceleration of the Universe will likely shed light on as yet undiscovered laws of physics. This project is part of an effort to use observations of the clustering of galaxies and the gravitational lensing caused by galaxies to determine the cause of the accelerated expansion of the Universe.

It is possible to constrain the possible causes of the accelerated expansion of the Universe (the unknown cause is usually referred to case "Dark Energy") by observing the manner in which galaxies cluster together and the manner in which galaxies cause an effect known as gravitational lensing, which very slightly distorts the images of distant galaxies. In order to provide meaningful constraints on the dark energy, these measurements must be made extremely precisely. Fortunately, contemporary and forthcoming astronomical surveys, such as the Dark Energy Survey (DES), the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI), and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) are all capable of measuring galaxy clustering and lensing with the required (and unprecedented precision). As of this writing, it seems likely that theoretical predictions for the quantities to be measured, the galaxy correlation function and the lensing correlation function, will be significantly less precise than the measurements. As a consequence, it may be that the most significant contribution to our future uncertainty on the nature of the dark energy will be induced by uncertainty in theoretical predictions. This project produced improved theoretical models for the galaxy clustering and lensing that will be observed by LSST and DESI in an effort to mitigate the theory induced uncertainty on future dark energy measurements.

A major uncertainty associated with predicting galaxy clustering and lensing stems from the uncertain process of galaxy and galaxy cluster formation. In this project, we developed and tested models to better handle the uncertainty due to galaxy formation in theoretical models of clustering and lensing as may be observed by LSST. We demonstrated the viability of these techniques to model realistic data without significantly degrading the ability of future measurements to constrain dark energy. This is a notable improvement over the prior approach. We built software implementations of these techniques that can now be used by the broader community and contributed to the software infrastructure of the LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration.

 In order to test our analysis techniques, it was necessary to build sets of mock data that mimic the characteristics of the data that will be acquired by LSST and DESI. As part of this project, we dedicates significant effort to the development of mock data sets. These mock data sets can be used by our research group and other members of the scientific community to test their analysis schemes. In the course of developing these mock data sets, we also identified several shortcomings of contemporary cosmological simulations that, while small, are non-negligible when it comes to the analysis of extremely high-precision data that future astronomical surveys will yield. These findings establish the domain of applicability of certain simulation programs and analysis software and provide guidance on how to further expand this domain.

 As part of the broader impacts of this project, the PI developed educational materials aimed at educating K-12 school teachers in astronomical science in order to enable them to bring this science into the classroom and better serve their students. This efforted was complemented by regular public lectures describing state of the art astronomical research in the sub-disciplines of dark energy and dark matter.
